awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Understanding Privacy Violations of Racial and Ethnic Minorities in Online Photo Sharing
awd_abstract_narration:
Photo sharing on social media is occurring at unprecedented rates; yet, the privacy of photo subjects and photo bystanders is frequently ignored during sharing. Viral internet ‘memes’ are often the result of embarrassing photos taken out of context, putting the photo subject at risk of cyber-bullying, shaming, and abuse. People from marginalized or vulnerable groups are especially at risk. The project’s novelties are to understand how social group memberships of people sharing photos and of photo targets influence online photo sharing. As such, the research team examines the contextual factors of the photo and the individual characteristics of photo perceivers that influence their willingness to share photo memes depicting strangers. The project’s broader significance and importance are to illuminate the role that bias plays in one of the most common modes of communication, as well as inform the creation of interventions that circumvent biased behavior on the part of social media users in the future. Moreover, this project paves the way for multiple new lines of research, as it pioneers a new stimulus set and methodology to understand how  intergroup biases influence privacy decisions and includes participants of various racial and ethnic groups.

The project includes a set of studies that is among the first to examine the role of bias and social group membership in privacy and sharing decisions on social media. Across the studies, the researchers validate a new stimulus set with photo-based memes representing diverse photo subjects and situations and examine the extent to which decisions to share photo memes of other people vary based on the group membership of participants and photo targets, using multiple behavioral methods.  Of primary interest is whether different groups of participants differentially protect the privacy of others across various social group memberships (e.g., gender, race, and age).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Photo-sharing practices on social media offer critical insights into how people treat the personal and private information of others. Recent work has theorized that virally-shared social media memes may be more likely to depict people from certain racial groups, with the potential for large-scale social consequences such as differential privacy concerns and the proliferation of stereotypes and prejudices. If we are to help people manage private information in a world that is increasingly lived online, we need to better understand through technological means and psychological methods what components of personality and behavior contribute to the disproportionate privacy violations of racial and ethnic minorities and dissemination of their personal information online.

We examined whether users demonstrate race-based photo sharing preferences in social media, as well as the extent to which age and humor styles modulate sharing biases. We found that White, Asian, and Black participants rated memes with Black targets as most negatively valenced and most shareable. In addition, we found that participants who scored higher in self-defeating humor styles were more likely to want to share memes. On the other hand, we found additional evidence to suggest that participants who feel more warmly (as measured by a ‘feeling thermometer’ scale) towards Black people have a higher sharing likelihood of memes with Black targets. Further, we also found that Asian and Black participants in particular were most likely to show in-group sharing preferences. These findings suggest that, although some individuals may proliferate bias through aggressive race-based sharing of memes that center Black individuals or through ignoring or under-representing Asian individuals, other social media users may increase positive representation of diverse individuals through affiliative meme sharing. Our results pave the way for a more nuanced understanding of how large-scale social media sharing may serve to proliferate or undermine racial stereotypes and prejudices. 

Digital privacy violations of racial and ethnic minorities in service of entertainment pose a significant challenge to overcoming intergroup bias in the United States. When internet users trade on others’ identities as entertainment when sharing memes, this both violates the others’ privacy and autonomy and treats them as a prop. Moreover, disseminating images that depict minorities in stereotypic ways creates a context where the viewer’s own biases become activated, which can have consequences for decision-making. The findings from the project bring to light the ways in which racial bias shapes one of the most common means of internet communication, meme sharing, and aid in understanding how these biases moderate the way individuals ascribe value to the personal and private information of certain categories of people. Importantly, this project informs the creation of interventions that circumvent discriminatory and biased behavior on the part of social media users in the future.
